application_type_full: Prior Approval: Change of use - offices to dwellinghouses
description: Change of use from Class B1a (Office) to Class C3 (Residential) to provide 69 no. dwellings.
decision_conditions: The proposed development is considered to be in accordance with Schedule 2, Part 3, Class O of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order (England) 2015 (as amended). Therefore, it is recommended that prior approval be granted.

No development shall commence until a site investigation scheme based on the desk study together with assessment of risks posed by any contamination is carried out in accordance with British Standard BS10175: Investigation of Potentially Contaminated Sites - Code of Practice and the Environment Agency's Model Procedures for the Management of Land Contamination (CLR 11) (or equivalent British Standard and Model Procedures if replaced), has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Should remediation be required, no development shall commence until a report specifying the measures to be taken, including the timescale, to remediate the site to render it suitable for use shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and to prevent harm to human health and pollution of the environment in accordance with Policy 5.21 of the London Plan, 2016.

Prior to occupation of the development, a verification report demonstrating completion of the works set out in the approved remediation strategy and the effectiveness of the remediation shall be submitted to and approved, in writing, by the local planning authority. The report shall include results of sampling and monitoring carried out in accordance with the approved verification plan to demonstrate that the site remediation criteria have been met. It shall also include any plan (a "long-term monitoring and maintenance plan") for longer-term monitoring of pollutant linkages, maintenance and arrangements for contingency action, as identified in the verification plan, if appropriate, and for the reporting of this to the local planning authority. Any long-term monitoring and maintenance plan shall be implemented as approved. Reason: Should remediation be deemed necessary, the applicant should demonstrate that any remedial measures have been undertaken as agreed and the environmental risks have been satisfactorily managed so that the site is deemed suitable for use and to prevent harm to human health and pollution of the environment in accordance with Policy 5.21 of the London Plan, 2016.

If during development, contamination not previously identified is found to be present at the site then no further development (unless otherwise agreed in writing with the Local Planning Authority) shall be carried out until the developer has submitted, and obtained written approval from the Local Planning Authority for, a remediation strategy detailing how this unsuspected contamination shall be dealt with. The remediation strategy shall be implemented as approved, verified and reported to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Reason: There is always the potential for unexpected contamination to be identified during development groundworks. The Local Planning Authority should be consulted should any contamination be identified that could present an unacceptable risk to Controlled Waters to prevent harm to human health and pollution of the environment in accordance with Policy 5.21 of the London Plan, 2016

A Car Park Management Plan demonstrating how the use of the car park will be controlled and detailing the signage necessary within the site to direct pedestrians and vehicles shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority prior to first occupation. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details and thereafter permanently retained.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policies DM9 (Managing Vehicle Use for New Development) and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The car parking, servicing and manoeuvring areas shown on the approved drawings shall be provided with a hard, bound, dust-free surface, adequately drained before the development is occupied for the purpose hereby permitted.  The respective areas shall be kept free from obstruction at all times, and shall not thereafter be used for any other purposes other than those shown on the approved drawing. Reason:  To ensure that the proposed development does not prejudice the free flow of traffic or conditions of general safety on adjoining highways and that adequate parking servicing and manoeuvring provision is made in accordance with Policies DM9 (Managing Vehicle Use for New Development) and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All works on site shall take place in accordance with a Construction Management Plan  including the following details which shall have previously been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to commencement: a) Statement on how the proposed development will be builtb) Provision for loading/unloading materials;c) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;d) Deliveries/collections to and from the site should use a route that is agreed with NRSWA team. The agreed route should be signed accordingly.e) Protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;f) Protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; andg) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site, and whether a banksman will be provided;h) Temporary site access;i) Signing system for works traffic;j) Site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads.k) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site.l) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;m) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;n) Location of all ancillary site buildings;o) Means of enclosure of the site; andp) Wheel washing equipment.q) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors.. Reason:  These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to first occupation, a Delivery and Service Plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved plan and thereafter permanently retained.Reason: In order to ensure proper delivery and service management in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to first occupation, details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development shall be carried out in accordance with the submitted Flood Risk Assessment by Stantec (ref 66758R2 rev 2; dated 30 January 2020) and the following mitigation measures it details:- No sleeping accommodation shall be located below the first floor levelThese mitigation measures shall be fully implemented prior to occupation and subsequently in accordance with the scheme's timing/phasing arrangements. The measures detailed above shall be retained and maintained thereafter throughout the lifetime of the development.Reason: To reduce the risk of flooding to future occupants in accordance with policies CS2 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to commencement of development a full Construction Logistics Plan should be provided that demonstrates that construction will not negatively impact the operation of the Transport for London Road Network (TLRN) nor reduce bus journey time reliability. Transport for London (TfL) have produced guidance for applicants producing Construction Logistics Plans (CLP), which should be followed. TfL's guidance can be accessed here:  http://content.tfl.gov.uk/construction-logistics-plan-guidance.pdf.- It is requested that the applicant uses FORS and CLOCS registered vehicles for all construction and delivery vehicles serving the site. However, the Mayor is in the process of implementing more stringent Direct Vision Standards (DVS) across London starting in October 2020. The applicant should make sure that all vehicles comply with the DVS standards also.- TfL requests that deliveries are not scheduled during peak hours. This is in the interests of road safety in line with the Mayor's Vision Zero target.- TfL requests that the applicant proposes the use of a banksman on site ensuring vehicles can enter and exit the site safely, and the management of pedestrians and cyclists, in line with the Vision Zero Standards.- TfL request evidence that vehicles can enter and exit in forward gear, this should take the form of a swept path analysis to ensure safety on the road in line with the Vision Zero Standards.- All vehicles associated with the installation works must only park/stop at permitted locations and within the time periods permitted by existing on-street restrictions.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to ensure proper delivery and service management in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Condition 3 (Materials) - Officers have reviewed the samples and information provided and are satisfied that they agree with those provided with the original permission. Officers are now satisfied this condition can be approved and will ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 3 (Materials) of planninng permission 17/16547/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

Consultations31no. surrounding owner/occupiers were notified of the proposals. No responses have been received. Historic EnglandGive authorisation for Local Authority to make assessment and determine. Maldens and Coombe Conservation Area Advisory Committee: No objections.Site and SurroundingsThe application site comprises a private residential management training centre and is situated approximately 2km north-east of Kingston upon Thames Town Centre. The wider area is predominantly residential in character. Coombe Wood Golf Club lies immediately north of the site and to the south, on the opposite side of George Road, there are three independent day schools comprising Holy Cross Preparatory School, Rokeby School and Marymount International School. The Four Acres Lodge and Gate piers are Grade-II Listed and the building is located within the Coombe Wood Conservation Area. ProposalThis application seeks listed building consent for the installation of security gates to the main entrance at Four Acres following removal of the existing wooden gates. The proposals also seeks listed building consent for minor resurfacing works. AssessmentThe main issues to consider when assessing this application relate to character and appearance and heritage. Character, Appearance, Heritage Together the NPPF, 2021 and the London Plan, 2021 operate to secure development of a high quality and where applicable replace poor design with better design.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012 require that proposals should relate well to their surroundings and be of a high standard to achieve a more attractive, sustainable and accessible environment.Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.In determining planning applications which affect heritage assets, Paragraph 197 of the NPPF 2021 requires local planning authorities to take account of the desirability of sustaining and enhancing the significance of heritage assets and putting them to viable uses consistent with their conservation, the positive contribution that conservation of heritage assets can make to sustainable communities including their economic vitality, and the desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character and distinctiveness.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, Paragraph 199 states that great weight should be given to the asset's conservation, irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Paragraph 201 says that where a proposed development will lead to substantial harm to (or total loss of) the significance of a designated heritage asset, permission should be refused unless it can be demonstrated that the harm or loss is necessary to achieve substantial public benefits that outweigh the harm or loss, or all of the following apply:- The nature of the heritage asset prevents all reasonable uses of the site;- No viable use of the heritage asset itself can be found in the medium term through appropriate marketing that will enable its conservation;- Conservation by grant-funding or some form of not for profit, charitable or public ownership is demonstrably not possible; and- The harm or loss is outweighed by the benefit of bringing the site back into use.Paragraph 202 goes on to say that where a development proposal will lead to less than substantial harm to the significance of a designated heritage asset, this harm should be weighed against the public benefits of the proposal including, where appropriate, securing its optimum viable use.Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.According to Paragraph 206, local planning authorities should look for opportunities for new development within conservation areas and within the setting of heritage assets in order to enhance or better reveal their significance. Proposals that preserve those elements of the setting that make a positive contribution to the asset (or which better reveal its significance) should be treated favourably.Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals affecting heritage assets, and their settings, should conserve their significance, by being sympathetic to the assets' significance and appreciation within their surroundings. The cumulative impacts of incremental change from development on heritage assets and their settings should also be actively managed. Development proposals should avoid harm and identify enhancement opportunities by integrating heritage considerations early on in the design process.Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special CharacterThe significance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character can be summarised as an area of exceptionally high quality landscape with important views both within and beyond the Borough.Coombe Wood Conservation AreaThe special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as large Victorian, Edwardian, and 20th-Century properties set in a semi-rural street scene around the open space occupied by Coombe Wood Golf Course.Officers consider that the proposal would not affect the ability to appreciate the significance of Coombe Wood Conservation Area and that the overall effect of the proposal on the Conservation Area would be neutral i.e. the proposal would preserve the setting of the Conservation Area.Historic England added the former lodge and gatepiers to the National List on 26 October 2001. The Listing description is as follows: "Former lodge and gate piers, now accommodation for management training centre. Circa 1929 by George Warren in Vernacular Revival style. Originally it would have housed servants from the main house, Four Acres. Built mainly of brick in stretcher bond but with central timber-framed gable with plastered infill, hipped tiled roof and two brick chimneystacks. One storey and attics: four windows. Casements replaced to original design in late C20. Front elevation has central timber-framed gable with carved bargeboards and band above eaves level. Overhang on wooden brackets to ground floor which has two plank doors. Ground floor has two casement windows. One hipped dormer window to each side and two to rear and four casement windows to ground floor. Adjoining are a pair of circular brick gatepiers with conoid tiled tops that form an ensemble with the lodge."The overall style of the main house is one of Vernacular Revival, and the gate piers tie in with this style. It is acknowledged that the original use of the lodge as servant's quarters has long since been absent, however, it retains architectural and historic interest as an early 20th Century former lodge.The listing of the application site confirms that it serves to make a positive contribution to the significance of the Conservation Area in its origins as an early 20th-century large, detached house within landscape grounds and relationship with the streetscene and the quality of its architecture.  The principle of entrance gates within this position is acceptable through historic justification as the gate piers suggest that there was once some form of enclosure at the entrance to the property. The brick, conical topped gate piers are of a unique and distinguishable character therefore any additions would need to remain subservient to this element in order for it to retain its special architectural interest. The design of the gates would be unobtrusive with a low profile, therefore it is considered that they would not result in an overbearing impact upon the character or design of the piers. By moving the gates back from the gate piers, their contact with the piers would be minimal and therefore the impact upon the integrity of the gate piers would be further reduced. The existing comprises a modern timber gate, and, so, the proposals would not result in the loss of any historic fabric. The proposed gates are to be of the same height as the existing timber gates and are proposed to be black-finished metal which are considered to be in keeping of the style and character of the building. Based on the style and appearance of the host lodge and main building, it is unlikely that the gate was historically timber, and therefore the proposed black finished, metal gates are considered to represent a more appropriate reflection of the significance of the building's entrance serving as the site's principal access. The boundary treatments within the area are of a mixed design and materiality. The proposed gates would not appear out of character within this part of the Conservation Area. The proposals also seek to replace the existing damaged driveway with porous asphalt. Security measures are additionally proposed in the form of security cameras and security sensor lighting to be positioned discreetly under the eaves of the lodge building. These elements of the application are considered to be minor alterations which would not have a harmful impact upon the heritage designation of the building and are acceptable. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be in keeping with the existing building on site and the immediate surrounding area, with no negative impacts identified to the historic environment through the installation of replacement gates on the Listed gatepiers, thereby complying with Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would be in-keeping with the character and appearance of the area. The proposed gates would enhance the appearance of the Grade-II Listed gate piers through their high-quality design and materiality, having due regard to Section 16 of the Planning (Listed Building and Conservation Area) Act 1990 permission should be granted. Furthermore, it is concluded that the proposal would not harm the designated heritage assets as per the requirements of the NPPF 2021. As such, the proposals are considered to comply with the NPPF, 2021, the London Plan, 2021 and the LDF Core Strategy, 2012.
The details have been assessed by the Highway Department and it is confirmed that the condition can be discharged subject to compliance with the Memorandum of Agreement

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.4 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the single storey rear extension would not strictly adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, in terms of depth (4m v.3-3.5m), given that the proposed development would have an appropriate height, officers consider it would not appear out of proportion to the original dwelling, and would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: While officers note that the adjoining properties do not benefit from existing rear extensions, given the modest height of the proposed development, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Consultations31no. surrounding owner/occupiers were notified of the proposals.  No responses have been received. RBK Tree and Landscaping Officer: No objections, subject to amendment to the Tree Protection Plan (TPP) to include annotation to state that the excavation for the new post is lined to prevent concrete leachates making contact with root matter (assuming the new posts will be positioned in the same locations as the existing posts). If new positions, then any new excavations will require the same lining treatment and will also need to have the initial 50cm dug by hand under arboricultural supervision. Officer Comment: Amended TPP submitted on 05.10.2021 to include the above annotation.Historic EnglandGive authorisation for Local Authority to make assessment and determine. Site and SurroundingsThe application site comprises a private residential management training centre and is situated approximately 2km north-east of Kingston upon Thames Town Centre. The wider area is predominantly residential in character. Coombe Wood Golf Club lies immediately north of the site and to the south and on the opposite side of George Road there are three independent day schools comprising Holy Cross Preparatory School, Rokeby School and Marymount International School. The Four Acres Lodge and Gate piers are Grade-II Listed and the building is located within the Coombe Wood Conservation Area. ProposalThis application seeks planning permission for the installation of security gates to the main entrance at Four Acres following removal of the existing wooden gates. The proposals also seeks permission for minor resurfacing works. AssessmentThe main issues to consider when assessing this application relate to character and appearance, impact upon heritage assets and residential amenity.Principle of DevelopmentThe principle of the installation of replacement gates is acceptable subject to compliance with Development Plan policies.Character and AppearanceTogether the NPPF, 2021 and the London Plan, 2021 operate to secure development of a high quality and where applicable replace poor design with better design and avoid harm and identify enhancement opportunities by integrating heritage considerations early on in the design process.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012 require that proposals should relate well to their surroundings and be of a high standard to achieve a more attractive, sustainable and accessible environment and set out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration.The principle of entrance gates within this position is acceptable through historic justification as the gate piers suggest that there was once some form of enclosure at the entrance to the property. The brick, conical topped gate piers are of a unique and distinguishable character, therefore any additions would need to remain subservient to this element in order for it to retain its special architectural interest. The design of the gates is unobtrusive with a low profile, therefore it is considered that there would not be any overbearing impact upon the character or design of the piers. By moving the gates back from the gate piers, their contact with the piers is minimal and, therefore, the impact upon the integrity of the gate piers is further reduced. The existing comprises a modern timber gate, and, so, the proposals would not result in the loss of any historic fabric. The proposed gates are to be of the same height as the existing timber gates and are proposed to be black-finished metal which are considered to be in keeping of the style and character of the building. Based on the style and appearance of the host lodge and main building, it is unlikely that the gate was historically timber. The proposed metal gates are considered to represent a more appropriate reflection of the significance of the building's entrance serving as the site's principal access. The boundary treatments within the area are of a mixed design and materiality. The proposed gates would not appear out of character within this part of the Conservation Area. The proposals also seek to replace the existing damaged driveway with porous asphalt. Security measures are additionally proposed in the form of security cameras and security sensor lighting to be positioned discreetly under the eaves of the lodge building. These elements of the application are considered to be minor alterations which would not have a harmful impact upon the heritage designation of the building and are acceptable. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be in keeping with the existing building on site and the immediate surrounding area, with no negative impacts or harm identified to the historic environment through the installation of replacement gates on the Listed gatepiers. In fact it is considered that the proposed gates would enhance the appearance of the Grade-II listed gate piers through their high-quality design and materiality. Therefore, the proposals are considered to comply with Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012.Residential AmenityParagraph 130 of the NPPF, 2021 and Policy D6 of the London Plan, 2021 seek to ensure that development secures a good standard of amenity for all existing and future users (of land and buildings).More specifically, Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012 seeks to safeguard residential amenity with regards to privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.However, it is considered that there would be no significant adverse amenity impact caused to neighbouring properties above and beyond the existing situation.  As such, the proposal is considered to be in accordance with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would be in-keeping with the character and appearance of the area and would not have any significant adverse impact upon neighbouring residential amenity. The proposed gates would enhance the appearance of the Grade-II Listed gate piers through their high-quality design and materiality. As such, the proposals are considered to comply with the NPPF, 2021, the London Plan, 2021, and the LDF Core Strategy, 2012.

The application site is located on the east side of South Lane just to the north of the crossroads of Groveland Way and Selwyn Road.The surrounding area is predominantly residential in character and appearance. The site is not in a conservation area and the buildings and curtilage are not statutorily or locally listed. 88 objections have been received objecting to the siting and appearance of the proposed telecoms apparatus. 4 representations is support have been received.The application seeks to determine whether the prior approval of the Local Planning Authority is required for the siting and appearance of the installation of 5G telecoms of H3G Phase 8 18m high street pole c/w wrap-around cabinet and 3 further additional equipment cabinets.The application has been assessed against the provisions of Schedule 2 Part 16 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 as amended. The application has also been assessed against the policies of the National Planning Policy Framework and the current Development Plan policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy.The National Planning Policy Framework 2021 is clear at paragraph 118 in as much as the Local Planning Authority should not question need. Local planning authorities must determine applications on planning grounds only. They should not seek to prevent competition between different operators, question the need for an electronic communications system, or set health safeguards different from the International Commission guidelines for public exposure.This application is for prior approval, not for planning permission. Prior approval is a light-touch process which applies where the principle of the development has already been established (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 028 Reference ID: 13-028-20140306).Prior approval means that a developer has to seek approval from the local planning authority that specified elements of the development are acceptable before work can proceed. The matters for prior approval vary depending on the type of development and these are set out in full in the relevant parts in Schedule 2 to the General Permitted Development Order. A local planning authority cannot consider any other matters when determining a prior approval application (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 026 Reference ID: 13-026-20140306).The main considerations of the case are: - Siting and; - AppearanceThe proposed telecom apparatus would be sited in a highly visible location  on South Lane opposite and adjacent to a number of residential properties.The height of the mast would be 20m which would be in excess of 8 to 10m higher than a standard telegraph pole (8m) and street lamp column (10m) which are typical other such perpendicular pieces of street furniture found in the locality. It is considered that the proposal would result in an incongruous addition to the streetscene that would be visually intrusive and create visual clutter and detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area.It is considered that the siting and appearance would be inappropriate in this case and it is recommended that prior approval be refused as it would not accord with policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.The need for an upgraded, modern telecommunications network is both acknowledged and appreciated, and indeed is given great weight in the decision making process; however, for the reasons cited above it is considered that the harm caused by the proposed installation would outweigh the benefits. In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably. Amendments required to make the application acceptable are substantial and would materially change the development proposal.  They would require further consultation to be undertaken prior to determination which could not take place within the statutory determination period specified by the Department of Communities and Local Government.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single storey rear extension 5.5m deep under a flat roof of approx 3mConsultationO Representations have been received (2 neighbours notified)AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Whilst the proposal would not be in strict accordance with the SPD, given the context of the site the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development, taking into account the permitted neighbouring extension and after applying the 45 degree guidance, would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Condition 10 (Delivery and Servicing Plan) - RBK Neighbourhood Engineer has reviewed the information submitted and is satisfied this can now be approved.The applicant should undertake the future surveys as indicated in the document and if as a result further significant changes are proposed Highways would request that these are resubmitted for review and feedback.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 10 (Delivery and Servicing Plan) of planning permission 20/03014/PAO2R is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.
Could you please advise of a postal address we could forward the laminated site notice to, for it to be posted up on site once the application has been validated.
The declaration section in the application form is signed by a different person, please revise the application form with the correct names.

The proposed site address in the submitted application form and location is for 24 and 24A Market Place,Kingston Upon Thames, KT1 1JH, whereas the red outline in the location plan is in 24 Market Place, please amend the location plan with the correct red outline in the proposed iste.Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.

Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.The submitted location plan is in 1:1000 scale.

Please provide a copy of proposed block plan scaled 1:500, providing a scale bar showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.The submitted block plan does not show the proposed development in hatched or shaded.

Please provide a copy of proposed block plan scaled 1:500, providing a scale bar showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.

Please provide existing and proposed roof plans at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work.The submitted existing first floor plan is labelled as existing roof plan, please revise the drawing with the correct labelling.

Please provide copies of all existing and proposed side elevations at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work.The submitted drawing has only one side elevation, we require two existing and proposed side elevations.

The fee required for your planning application is £ 145.00.  Payment can be made via either our Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002, by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames or online via the Kingston council website.
The site address in the form, block plan and location plan is different, please submit the location plan and form with the correct proposed address.
